p: What are the MAPs? According to Maiti and Geetha [ 174], MAPs are plants that provide “medicines” to humans that prevent disease, maintain health, or cure illnesses; “let food be your medicine”, attributed to Hippocrates, 460–377 B.C., is again a popular concept. New designations have emerged to classify the beneficial effects of the use of some plants or plant parts and products. According to Barata et al. [ 172], MAPs can be divided into four groups, based on their final usage: raw materials for essential oil extraction, which is the major use of MAPs around the world; spices, nonleafy parts of plants used as flavouring or seasoning; herbs, leafy or soft flowering parts of the plant used as flavouring or seasoning; miscellaneous group, MAPs used in different ways.
